Award.AbstractNarration:
The project addresses open problems in noncommutative analysis, mathematical physics, noncommutative geometry, and operator theory in the operator algebras framework. One of the objectives is to advance recent powerful results on multiple operator integrals and spectral shift functions that have been obtained jointly with D. Potapov and F. Sukochev. New noncommutative analysis techniques will be developed and applied to various problems of perturbation theory that have arisen in the areas mentioned above. Another objective is to make progress in understanding structure of important operators affiliated with von Neumann algebras, continuing investigation started jointly with K. Dykema.

The proposed research is expected to strengthen connections between several areas of mathematics and to make a link to modern studies in physics. Many of the projects are accessible to students, at both graduate and undergraduate levels. The investigator proposes to contribute to general education in the respective areas of mathematics as well as involve students into specific projects. The results of the proposed research will be disseminated to the worldwide scientific community through publications and talks. This will include writing expository articles and delivering talks to students. The investigator will continue organizing conferences and popularizing careers in mathematics among youth and underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was dedicated to solving open problems in operator theory and to  advancing related methods for operator theoretic models of quantum mechanics that are studied in mathematical physics and noncommutative geometry. The obtained results include the following: a breakthrough on perturbation theory of differential operators, pioneering results on perturbation of general continuous traces on normed ideals, trace formulas for perturbation of single- and multivariable operator functions, new understanding of structure of traceless operators, development of new noncommutative analysis methods via subtle synthesis of various techniques in analysis and operator theory.

The project has also contributed to education and training of students. The PI has developed and taught a topics course for pre-REU undergraduate students and two topics courses for graduate students. In addition, an undergraduate student has written a thesis on one of the topics of the project and entered the mathematics graduate program at UNM. A PhD student  has been working on a dissertation on one of topics of the project. The PI has (co)organized two miniconferences on analysis and two special sessions on operator theory at different conferences. The PI has given numerous talks at conferences and colloquia for professional mathematicians and also at UNM for undergraduate students.The undergaduate student of the PI has made a presentation at an undegraduate research conference.
